data.text: Bikepacking Low Rider Fork Racks to Mount a Fork Bag

Fork Racks?? my multiday off-road rides this year will include camping. Fork bags seem popular but how to mount them? My son has 3 bosses on his forks, I've got one, which goes right through the fork, plus 2 threaded holes at the bottom ... So am I right in thinking my son's bike will take something like https://www.planetx.co.uk/i/q/BAPODTFB/podsacs-tarpaulin-fork-dry-bag-and-rack-(4-litre) but I need a 'low rider' rack?? How does adding weight to the wheel help the ride over bumps? Seems like bad place for fork flex/suspension, even if good for stability?? Do low-riders snag in ruts / cope with narrow paths ... I assume the bags take quite a beating? Do you use them? What are they like in practice? Thanks :)

Iâ€™d use the one bolt you have, plus insulation tape to protect the fork leg, plus some heavy duty cable ties (the type with the prominent release trigger). They are really good, Iâ€™ve got a set of both the smaller and larger Planet X bags. I use the larger ones to carry my cooker and food in one, and my Alpkit Dirtbag mat in the other. You can even mount them on a fork with no bolts at allâ€¦I went touring on my carbon roadie and it was fine.

data.text:
As Iain says, single mid fork bolt is not a bar to these type of cages and bags. There are a myriad of options to add extra bolts. It looks like you have a Genesis Vagabond? I had one and I used these https://www.decathlon.co.uk/p/universal-bottle-cage-mount-black/_/R-p-143406 to provide extra bolts with a spacer and longer bolt on the frame boss. I've also used them to fit one of these type cages and bags to Brompton for bikepacking without any fixed bosses. Electrical tape underneath to protect the paint. They gave a rock solid result for Salsa anything cages to carry a dry bag with sleeping bag, stove, tent type things. The world remains your oyster.
